computer.description:
The EXL 100 was done by people who worked at Texas Instruments. It uses a lot of technologies of the TI CC40 (like the basic and the CPU for exemple). All the hardware is based on Texas Instruments chips. The TMS 7020 is the CPU, the TMS 7041 manages all I/O, the speech synthesizer (TMS 5220) and the infrared receiver. The keyboard and the joysticks are linked by infrared to the CPU.
Several peripherals were developped for this computer : a dot matrix printer (EXL 80) and a modem (ExelModem). This computer didn't have a great market success. It was above all used in schools.

overview||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> OVERVIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>Exeldrums is quite an original expansion. It plugs at the rear of the system and acts as a digital drum machine with a built-in sequencer ! It has been developped with Hohner. <br><br> The EXL-100 can thus play 6 different instruments at the same time chosen from 17. There are already 16 rythm presets built-in the system, and 54 more can be created. The output is stereo and can be connected to a hi-fi through the "audio output" socket. Quite impressive.</blockquote>

It can be used with the Exelvision computers as well as other computers. It's a impact-matrix printer with a 9-pins printing head. The character matrix is of 7 by 9 points. It can print 100 characters / sec. and has an optimised bi-directional printing. It has 96 different characters (ASCII). The graphical resolution is 72 x 72 dpi. <br><br> Printing density : 10, 12, 15 or 16.6 characters/inch<br> Line spacing : 6 and 8 lines/inch<br> Printing attributes : double height, double width, underline<br> Printing field : 203.2 mm<br> Interfaces : Parallel/Centronic, Serial V24 (otional), Videotex (optional), RS-422/RS-485 (optional), IEEE-488 (optional)</blockquote>

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> TELEMATIC PACK</strong></font><br><blockquote>This pack was composed of an EXL-100, a monochrom monitor, a "pro" keyboard, an Exelmodem expansion and a 16k Exelmémoire.</blockquote>

The case shape is slightly different, the Exeldisk is called EXL-188 (instead of the future EXL-135), the spacebar is dark grey and the joystick is light grey.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRONT</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right :<br> - Joysticks drawer (grey),<br> - Cartridge slot,<br> - Infra-red receiver,<br> - Reset button,<br> - ON/OFF switch.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UNDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>At the bottom left corner we can see the video cable going out... Next to it is the tape-recorder connector. Both are quite difficult to reach, but once connected you can be sure that they are gonna stay where they are !</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUBBER KEYBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the original infra-red keyboard. The rubber keys do not provide a pleasant feeling and keys have to be pressed one by one (because of the infra-red feature) even when you use SHIFT or CTL ! <br><br> There are some keys (orange) used to emulate a french minitel.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> EXELBASIC OVERLAY</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture shows the original rubber keyboard with the plastic overlay provided with the Exelbasic cartridge. Basic statements are thus written above the keys. <br><br> Funny thing : the SHIFT key is blank on the keyboard. But with the overlay you discover the function of the key, since "SHIFT" is written on it. It looks like they forgot to print SHIFT on the key when producing the keyboard, and corrected their error with the overlay...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> OPENED KEYBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the battery cell used to send infra-red signals to the main unit.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JOYSTICKS DRAWER</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is where are stored the infra-red joysticks ! Clever...</blockquote>
